user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_:
```c
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  const char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  const char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
{
  char *header_malloced;
  char *value_malloced;

  mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
  mhd_assert (0 != content_len);
  header_malloced = malloc (header_len + 1);
  if (NULL == header_malloced)
    return false;

  memcpy (header_malloced, header, header_len);
  header_malloced[header_len] = 0;

  value_malloced = malloc (content_len + 1);
  if (NULL != value_malloced)
  {
    memcpy (value_malloced, content, content_len);
    value_malloced[content_len] = 0;

    if (MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (response, kind,
                                          header_malloced, header_len,
                                          value_malloced, content_len))
      return true; /* Success exit point */

    free (value_malloced);
  }
  free (header_malloced);

  return false; /* Failure exit point */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 14.3 concerns invariant controlling expressions. The only controlling statements in this function are the three if-statements listed above, so those are the only fragments that could potentially contain invariant (constant) controlling expressions and therefore need inspection. There are no loops or other conditional constructs in the function. The mhd_assert(...) calls are macro invocations that do not appear here as explicit control statements in the source shown; the parameter expressions (header_len, content_len) are function parameters (not constants) and the malloc checks and the function-call condition depend on runtime results, so no other fragments present in the code are candidates for invariant controlling expressions and do not require further investigation.
